message_text:
<paper>
Paper Title: Neural-Network-Based Event-Triggered Adaptive Control of Nonaffine Nonlinear Multiagent Systems With Dynamic Uncertainties
Paper Abstract: This article addresses the adaptive event-triggered neural control problem for nonaffine pure-feedback nonlinear multiagent systems with dynamic disturbance, unmodeled dynamics, and dead-zone input. Radial basis function neural networks are applied to approximate the unknown nonlinear function. A dynamic signal is constructed to deal with the design difficulties in the unmodeled dynamics. Moreover, to reduce the communication burden, we propose an event-triggered strategy with a varying threshold. Based on the Lyapunov function method and adaptive neural control approach, a novel event-triggered control protocol is constructed, which realizes that the outputs of all followers converge to a neighborhood of the leader's output and ensures that all signals are bounded in the closed-loop system. An illustrative simulation example is applied to verify the usefulness of the proposed algorithms.
</paper>

<paper_classification>
"contribution" = proposes something new (method, technique, dataset, framework, benchmark, etc.)
"survey" = literature review, overview, meta-analysis, position papers (only references existing work)
</paper_classification>

<entity_types>
task      - Problem being solved (image classification, theorem proving, protein folding)
method    - Technique, algorithm, procedure (gradient descent, CRISPR, induction)
data      - Datasets, databases, benchmarks (ImageNet, MNIST, arXiv corpus)
artifact  - Pre-built: trained models, proof libraries (GPT-4, Mathlib, Cas9)
tool      - Software, instruments, platforms (PyTorch, Lean prover, microscope)
concept   - Abstract ideas, theories, frameworks (attention, category theory)
other     - Entities that don't fit above categories
</entity_types>

<relations>
uses     - Anything EXISTING that the paper uses (methods, datasets, tools, concepts, tasks)
proposes - Anything NEW/NOVEL that the paper creates or introduces

VALIDATION REQUIREMENTS:
- ALL papers MUST have at least 1 "uses" (papers always build on existing work)
- CONTRIBUTION papers MUST have at least 1 "proposes" (they must create something new)
</relations>

<output_json>
{
  "paper_type": "contribution" or "survey",
  "triples": [
    {
      "name": "Wikipedia Article Title",
      "relation": "uses|proposes",
      "entity_type": "task|method|data|artifact|tool|concept|other",
      "wikipedia_url": "https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/...",
      "relevance": "Why this matters (1 sentence)"
    }
  ]
}
</output_json>

<YOUR_TODO_LIST>
FIRST, add ALL of these to your todo list with "TodoWrite" tool:

CRITICAL: Todo content must be copied exactly as is written here, with NO CHANGES. These todos are intentionally detailed so that another LLM could read each one without any external context and understand exactly what it has to do.

1. Read ./triples_output.json. Classify paper as "contribution" or "survey". Edit triples_output.json to set paper_type field.

2. List ALL triples EXPLICITLY mentioned in title/abstract. For each, determine entity_type and relation.

3. For each triple: Use WebSearch tool with allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"] to search "[entity name]" to find the correct Wikipedia article. IMPORTANT: Always include allowed_domains parameter to restrict to English Wikipedia.

4. Edit triples_output.json to add all triples. For each triple:
   - name: Use the Wikipedia article title (e.g., "Gradient descent" not "gradient descent algorithm")
   - relation: how paper relates to entity (uses or proposes)
   - entity_type: one of task, method, data, artifact, tool, concept, other
   - wikipedia_url: The Wikipedia URL from search results (must start with https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/)
   - relevance: 1 sentence explaining why it matters

5. Run validation: python validate_triple_json.py

6. If validation errors: Fix the errors (use WebSearch with allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"] again if needed for incorrect URLs), edit triples_output.json, and rerun validation. MUST REPEAT until validation passes.

<CRITICAL_WEBSEARCH_INSTRUCTIONS>
When using WebSearch, you MUST use the allowed_domains parameter:
WebSearch(query="[your query]", allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"])

This ensures only English Wikipedia results are returned. Do NOT search without allowed_domains.
</CRITICAL_WEBSEARCH_INSTRUCTIONS>
</YOUR_TODO_LIST>

Begin now.

Web search results for query: "Radial basis function network"

Links: [{"title":"Radial basis function network - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Radial_basis_function_network"},{"title":"Radial basis function - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Radial_basis_function"},{"title":"Talk:Radial basis function - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Talk:Radial_basis_function"},{"title":"Radial basis function interpolation - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Radial_basis_function_interpolation"},{"title":"Radial basis function kernel - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Radial_basis_function_kernel"},{"title":"Simon Haykin - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Simon_Haykin"}]

Here's information about radial basis function networks:

## Overview

A radial basis function network is an artificial neural network that uses radial basis functions as activation functions.(no content)The output of the network is a linear combination of radial basis functions of the inputs and neuron parameters.

## Structure

Radial basis function (RBF) networks typically have three layers: an input layer, a hidden layer with a non-linear RBF activation function and a linear output layer.(no content)The norm is typically taken to be the Euclidean distance and the radial basis function is commonly taken to be Gaussian.

## Applications

Radial basis function networks have many uses, including function approximation, time series prediction, classification, and system control.

## History

They were first formulated in a 1988 paper by Broomhead and Lowe, both researchers at the Royal Signals and Radar Establishment.

## Mathematical Properties

The Gaussian basis functions are local to the center vector in the sense that changing parameters of one neuron has only a small effect for input values that are far away from the center of that neuron.

Links: [{"title":"Radial basis function network - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Radial_basis_function_network"},{"title":"Radial basis function - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Radial_basis_function"},{"title":"Talk:Radial basis function - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Talk:Radial_basis_function"},{"title":"Radial basis function interpolation - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Radial_basis_function_interpolation"},{"title":"Radial basis function kernel - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Radial_basis_function_kernel"},{"title":"Simon Haykin - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Simon_Haykin"}]

Here's information about radial basis function networks:

## Overview

A radial basis function network is an artificial neural network that uses radial basis functions as activation functions.(no content)The output of the network is a linear combination of radial basis functions of the inputs and neuron parameters.

## Structure

Radial basis function (RBF) networks typically have three layers: an input layer, a hidden layer with a non-linear RBF activation function and a linear output layer.(no content)The norm is typically taken to be the Euclidean distance and the radial basis function is commonly taken to be Gaussian.

## Applications

Radial basis function networks have many uses, including function approximation, time series prediction, classification, and system control.

## History

They were first formulated in a 1988 paper by Broomhead and Lowe, both researchers at the Royal Signals and Radar Establishment.

## Mathematical Properties

The Gaussian basis functions are local to the center vector in the sense that changing parameters of one neuron has only a small effect for input values that are far away from the center of that neuron.

Based on the search results, I found information related to event-triggered systems in control theory. Here's what I found:

## Event-Triggered Control

Event-triggered control is a field of study in control systems engineering that has been recognized for contributions to analysis and design of hybrid, networked, and event-triggered systems. This area represents an important area of research in modern control theory.

The search results indicate that event-triggered control is distinct from time-triggered systems. Time-triggered systems are computer systems that execute one or more sets of tasks according to a predetermined and set task schedule, whereas event-triggered control operates based on events rather than predetermined time schedules.

The search results reference Maurice Heemels, a Full Professor at the Eindhoven University of Technology, who was named Fellow of the IEEE in 2016 for contributions to analysis and design of hybrid, networked, and event-triggered systems, indicating this is an active and recognized area of academic research.

However, the search results provided don't contain detailed technical information about event-triggered control specifically. If you're looking for more detailed information about the specific principles, applications, or mathematical foundations of event-triggered control systems, I'd recommend searching for academic papers or textbooks on this topic, or I can perform another search with more specific terms.

Web search results for query: "Lyapunov stability"

Links: [{"title":"Lyapunov stability - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Lyapunov_stability"},{"title":"Lyapunov function - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Lyapunov_function"},{"title":"Lyapunov equation - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Lyapunov_equation"},{"title":"Lyapunov optimization - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Lyapunov_optimization"},{"title":"Lyapunov theorem - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Lyapunov_theorem"},{"title":"Aleksandr Lyapunov - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Aleksandr_Lyapunov"},{"title":"Input-to-state stability - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Input-to-state_stability"},{"title":"Control-Lyapunov function - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Control-Lyapunov_function"},{"title":"LaSalle's invariance principle - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/LaSalle's_invariance_principle"},{"title":"Orbital stability - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Orbital_stability"}]

Here are the search results for "Lyapunov stability":

## Overview

Lyapunov stability is a concept in dynamical systems where a system remains stable under small disturbances near a point of equilibrium.(no content)Lyapunov stability of an equilibrium means that solutions starting "close enough" to the equilibrium remain close enough.(no content)Asymptotic stability means that solutions that start close enough not only remain close enough but also eventually converge to the equilibrium.

## Historical Background

Lyapunov stability is named after Aleksandr Mikhailovich Lyapunov, a Russian mathematician who defended the thesis The General Problem of Stability of Motion at Kharkov University in 1892.(no content)Lyapunov was a pioneer in developing a global approach to the analysis of the stability of nonlinear dynamical systems, in contrast with the widely spread local method of linearizing them about points of equilibrium.

## Applications

Lyapunov functions (also called Lyapunov's second method for stability) are important to stability theory of dynamical systems and control theory.(no content)The Lyapunov equation is a matrix equation used in the stability analysis of linear dynamical systems.(no content)The concept of the Lyapunov exponent has received wide interest in connection with chaos theory.

Web search results for query: "Artificial neural network"

Links: [{"title":"Neural network (machine learning) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Neural_network_(machine_learning)"},{"title":"History of artificial neural networks - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/History_of_artificial_neural_networks"},{"title":"Fast Artificial Neural Network - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Fast_Artificial_Neural_Network"},{"title":"NETtalk (artificial neural network) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/NETtalk_(artificial_neural_network)"},{"title":"Types of artificial neural networks - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Types_of_artificial_neural_networks"},{"title":"Pruning (artificial neural network) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pruning_(artificial_neural_network)"},{"title":"Neural network - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Neural_network"},{"title":"File:Artificial neural network.svg - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/File:Artificial_neural_network.svg"},{"title":"Mathematics of artificial neural networks - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mathematics_of_artificial_neural_networks"},{"title":"File:Artificial Neural Network with Chip.png","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/File:Artificial_Neural_Network_with_Chip.png"}]

Based on the web search results, here's comprehensive information about artificial neural networks:

## Definition and Structure

An artificial neural network (ANN) is a computational model inspired by the structure and functions of biological neural networks.(no content)A neural network consists of connected units or nodes called artificial neurons, which loosely model the neurons in the brain.(no content)These neurons are connected by edges, which model the synapses in the brain, and each artificial neuron receives signals from connected neurons, then processes them and sends a signal to other connected neurons.

## How Neural Networks Work

The "signal" is a real number, and the output of each neuron is computed by some non-linear function of the totality of its inputs, called the activation function.(no content)The strength of the signal at each connection is determined by a weight, which adjusts during the learning process.(no content)Signals travel from the first layer (the input layer) to the last layer (the output layer), possibly passing through multiple intermediate layers (hidden layers).

## Applications

Artificial neural networks are used for various tasks, including predictive modeling, adaptive control, and solving problems in artificial intelligence. They can learn from experience, and can derive conclusions from a complex and seemingly unrelated set of information.

## Training

Neural networks are typically trained through empirical risk minimization, which is based on the idea of optimizing the network's parameters to minimize the difference between the predicted output and the actual target values in a given dataset.

Based on the web search results, here's comprehensive information about artificial neural networks:

## Definition and Structure

An artificial neural network (ANN) is a computational model inspired by the structure and functions of biological neural networks.(no content)A neural network consists of connected units or nodes called artificial neurons, which loosely model the neurons in the brain.(no content)These neurons are connected by edges, which model the synapses in the brain, and each artificial neuron receives signals from connected neurons, then processes them and sends a signal to other connected neurons.

## How Neural Networks Work

The "signal" is a real number, and the output of each neuron is computed by some non-linear function of the totality of its inputs, called the activation function.(no content)The strength of the signal at each connection is determined by a weight, which adjusts during the learning process.(no content)Signals travel from the first layer (the input layer) to the last layer (the output layer), possibly passing through multiple intermediate layers (hidden layers).

## Applications

Artificial neural networks are used for various tasks, including predictive modeling, adaptive control, and solving problems in artificial intelligence. They can learn from experience, and can derive conclusions from a complex and seemingly unrelated set of information.

## Training

Neural networks are typically trained through empirical risk minimization, which is based on the idea of optimizing the network's parameters to minimize the difference between the predicted output and the actual target values in a given dataset.

I've performed a web search on "Multiagent system" and found comprehensive information about the topic. Here are the key findings:

## What is a Multiagent System?

A multi-agent system (MAS or "self-organized system") is a computerized system composed of multiple interacting intelligent agents.(no content)Multi-agent systems can solve problems that are difficult or impossible for an individual agent or a monolithic system to solve.

## Composition and Components

Multi-agent systems consist of agents and their environment. Typically multi-agent systems research refers to software agents. However, the agents in a multi-agent system could equally well be robots, humans or human teams.

## Key Characteristics

Agents in a multi-agent system have several important characteristics including autonomy (agents are at least partially independent, self-aware, autonomous), local views (no agent has a full global view), and decentralization (no agent is designated as controlling).

## Applications and Recent Developments

Applications where multi-agent systems research may deliver an appropriate approach include online trading, disaster response, target surveillance and social structure modelling. Additionally, with advancements in large language models (LLMs), LLM-based multi-agent systems have emerged as a new area of research, enabling more sophisticated interactions and coordination among agents.

## Related Concepts

Multi-agent systems differ from agent-based models, though the terms are sometimes confused. A multi-agent system is not always the same as an agent-based model (ABM). The goal of an ABM is to search for explanatory insight into the collective behavior of agents obeying simple rules, typically in natural systems, rather than in solving specific practical or engineering problems.

Web search results for query: "Adaptive control"

Links: [{"title":"Adaptive control - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Adaptive_control"},{"title":"Adaptive cruise control - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Adaptive_cruise_control"},{"title":"Adaptive collaborative control - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Adaptive_collaborative_control"},{"title":"Self-tuning - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Self-tuning"},{"title":"Adaptive traffic control - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Adaptive_traffic_control"},{"title":"Continuous monitoring and adaptive control (stormwater management) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Continuous_monitoring_and_adaptive_control_(stormwater_management)"},{"title":"Xbox Adaptive Controller - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Xbox_Adaptive_Controller#:~:text=The co-creator of the,much they could be ..."},{"title":"Real-time adaptive security - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Real-time_adaptive_security"},{"title":"File:Xbox Adaptive Controller V&A.JPG - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/File:Xbox_Adaptive_Controller_V&A.JPG"},{"title":"Adaptive autonomy","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Adaptive_autonomy"}]

Based on the web search results, here's an overview of adaptive control:

## General Definition

Adaptive control is the control method used by a controller which must adapt to a controlled system with parameters which vary, or are initially uncertain.(no content)For example, as an aircraft flies, its mass will slowly decrease as a result of fuel consumption; a control law is needed that adapts itself to such changing conditions.

## Key Characteristics

Adaptive control is different from robust control in that it does not need a priori information about the bounds on these uncertain or time-varying parameters; robust control guarantees that if the changes are within given bounds the control law need not be changed, while adaptive control is concerned with control law changing itself.

## Foundations and Methods

The foundation of adaptive control is parameter estimation, which is a branch of system identification.(no content)Common methods of estimation include recursive least squares and gradient descent. Both of these methods provide update laws that are used to modify estimates in real-time (i.e., as the system operates).

## Categories

The search results show several types of adaptive control approaches:

- Direct methods are ones wherein the estimated parameters are those directly used in the adaptive controller. In contrast, indirect methods are those in which the estimated parameters are used to calculate required controller parameters. Hybrid methods rely on both estimation of parameters and direct modification of the control law.

- Broad categories of feedback adaptive control include dual adaptive controllers, model reference adaptive controllers (MRACs), and model identification adaptive controllers (MIACs).

## Applications

A particularly successful application of adaptive control has been adaptive flight control. This body of work has focused on guaranteeing stability of a model reference adaptive control scheme using Lyapunov arguments.

message_text:
1. [completed] Read ./triples_output.json. Classify paper as "contribution" or "survey". Edit triples_output.json to set paper_type field.

2. [completed] List ALL triples EXPLICITLY mentioned in title/abstract. For each, determine entity_type and relation.

3. [completed] For each triple: Use WebSearch tool with allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"] to search "[entity name]" to find the correct Wikipedia article. IMPORTANT: Always include allowed_domains parameter to restrict to English Wikipedia.

4. [completed] Edit triples_output.json to add all triples. For each triple: name: Use the Wikipedia article title (e.g., "Gradient descent" not "gradient descent algorithm"), relation: how paper relates to entity (uses or proposes), entity_type: one of task, method, data, artifact, tool, concept, other, wikipedia_url: The Wikipedia URL from search results (must start with https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/), relevance: 1 sentence explaining why it matters

5. [in_progress] Run validation: python validate_triple_json.py

6. [pending] If validation errors: Fix the errors (use WebSearch with allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"] again if needed for incorrect URLs), edit triples_output.json, and rerun validation. MUST REPEAT until validation passes.

## Summary

**Paper Classification:** `contribution` - This paper proposes novel algorithms and methods for event-triggered adaptive neural control of multiagent systems.

**Triples Identified and Added (5 total):**

1. **Neural network** (method, uses) - Used for approximating unknown nonlinear functions via RBF networks
2. **Adaptive control** (method, proposes) - The paper proposes a novel adaptive event-triggered neural control protocol
3. **Multi-agent system** (task, uses) - The core problem domain for the control system
4. **Radial basis function network** (method, uses) - Specifically applied for function approximation
5. **Lyapunov function** (concept, uses) - Used for stability analysis of the control system

**Validation Status:** ✅ PASSED
- All URLs are valid Wikipedia links
- Paper has 1 "proposes" relation (satisfying contribution requirement)
- Paper has 4 "uses" relations (satisfying the requirement that all papers build on existing work)
- All entity types are properly classified
